awd_titl_txt: Conference: Synergies between Nonparametrics, Sequential Analysis and Modern Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The Department of Statistics at the University of Michigan will host the conference titled “Synergies between Nonparametrics, Sequential Analysis and Modern Data Science” on the Ann Arbor campus from September 29 to 30, 2023.  The conference will feature non-parallel sessions with talks on current research in statistics and probability by distinguished speakers.  There will also be a poster session to give PhD students, postdocs, and junior professors an opportunity to present and receive feedback on their research.  Beyond the educational value from the presentations, the conference should serve to foster collaboration and discussion among the speakers, faculty, and students participating in the event.  Most of the funds from the NSF award will be used to support student participation in the conference, especially travel funds for non-local students.

Planned session topics for the conference include: sequential analysis to reinforcement learning; shape constraints and beyond; limit theorems for dependent data; modern data science; nonparametrics and selection biases; and astrostatistics in the 21st century.  For more information or to register to participate, please see the conference web-page: https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/woodroofememorial/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF grant funds were used to support a conference titled Synergies between Nonparametrics, Sequential Analysis and Modern Data Science.This conference was hosted by the Department of Statistics at the University of Michigan, and held at the UM campus in Ann Arbor from September 29 to 30, 2023.  The conference had 15 invited presentations by leading researchers in statistics, delivered in 6 sessions as follows.

       1.  Modern Data Science:

  • Sampling bias: eﬀects, tests and connection to AI biases. Jiayang  Sun, George Mason University.
  • Eﬃcient multimodal sampling via tempered distribution flow.  Xiao  Wang, Purdue University.
  • Repeated significance test and multi-armed bandits.  Cun-Hui Zhang, Rutgers University.

       2.  Shape Constraints and Beyond:

  • Michael Woodroofe and shape constraints.  Jon Wellner, University of Washington.
  • A mixture covariance estimator for inference in constrained  regression models.  Mary Meyer, Colorado State University.

       3.  Michael Woodroofe's Research Contributions:

  • Michael Woodroofe and the central limit theorem.  Persi Diaconis, Stanford University.
  • Michael Woodroofe and sequential analysis.  David Siegmund, Stanford University.

       4.  Limit Theorems for Dependent Data:

  • On a central limit theorem for arrays of stationary martingale.  diﬀerences.  Dalibor Volny, Universite de Rouen, France.
  • Change point analysis with irregular signals: when did the COVID-19  pandemic start?  Wei Biao Wu, University of Chicago.
  • Symmetric projective conditions for additive functionals of Markov  chains.  Magda Peligrad, University of Cincinnati.

       5.  Sequential Methods in Clinical Trials:

  • Information trade-oﬀs in two-stage group sequential designs.  Nancy  Flournoy, University of Missouri.
  • Fully sequential monitoring in clinical trials.  Dong-Yun Kim, OBR/NHLBI/NIH.

       6.  Astrostatistics in the 21st Century:

  • Analysis of truncated data with application to astronomy.  Zhiliang  Ying, Columbia University.
  • Chasing dark matter with Michael: A (brief) history and future  prospects.  Mario Mateo, University of Michigan.
  • An anti-search for cold dark matter halos on sub-galactic  scales.  Matthew Walker, Carnegie Mellon University.

In addition to these sessions with invited presentations, there was a Poster Session providing an opportunity for graduate students to present and receive feedback on their work, with recognition for outstanding achievement.

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2024
Modified by: Robert W Keener
